results.title: Results day:  How to stay positive and move forward
results.subtitle: Worried about your exam results? Good Thinking provides some practical tips to help teenagers across London before, during and after results day.

metadata.description: Worried about your exam results? Good Thinking provides some practical tips to help teenagers across London with the stress of results day.
metadata.title: Results day:  How to stay positive and move forward

contentSections.content:
Hopefully you’re enjoying the break from your studies and having a fantastic summer! But you might also be wondering how you’ve done in your GCSEs, A Levels, AS levels or vocational and technical qualifications (VTQs) and feeling nervous or anxious ahead of results day. 

This kind of stressful situation can result in various physical and psychological symptoms, including having racing thoughts, losing your appetite, experiencing aches and pains, not being able to concentrate and having trouble sleeping. 

It’s important to remember that getting your exam results is the start of an exciting new chapter. As the charity YoungMinds says, “Although results day is built up to be a life-determining event, there are many new days and new opportunities ahead of you.”

To help you cope with the stress of results day, the Good Thinking team has put together some tips and links to other useful resources.

tabs.title: Focus on what you can control
tabs.content:
We use the phrase ‘focus on what you can control’ a lot here at Good Thinking – because it’s really helpful! 

In your current situation, it means try not to worry about what grades you’re going to get (you’ve done your best and it's now in the hands of the exam board). Instead, put your energy into all the positive things you can do this summer, such as:

  • Seeing friends and family
  • Exercising regularly
  • Spending time in nature
  • Getting some work experience
  • Supporting a cause you believe in
  • Taking up a new hobby
  • Catching up on sleep

If you’re waiting to find out if you’ve got into uni, it’s a good idea to create a list of back-up options that you could explore through Clearing if you need to. You might also like to revisit your personal statement and prepare for possible phone interviews on results day. Clearing is a great option if your grades are not what you expected – in 2024, more than 68,000 students secured their university places this way.

tabs.title: Find out what happens on results day
tabs.content:
Another way to focus on what you can control is to know exactly what happens on results day and immediately afterwards. Here are a few things to do in advance so that it doesn’t seem so daunting:

  • Confirm what time your school or college will open on results day
  • Decide if you want to collect your results on your own or with a friend or relative
  • Find out which teachers will be there to provide advice and support
  • Make sure your phone is fully charged and topped up
  • Put any important phone numbers in your phone (e.g. your firm and insurance universities, your chosen college or sixth form and any potential employers)
  • Pack a pen and paper so you can take notes if you need to make calls to colleges, universities and/or employers on the day
  • Plan your journey and allow extra time for any transport delays
  • Work out where there’ll be a quiet place to sit if you need some space after getting your results

If you’ve applied to university, make sure your UCAS details are up-to-date and have your UCAS number and log-in and your Clearing number to hand (and remember, the UCAS hub will be very busy on results day, so you’ll need to be patient).

tabs.title: Be honest about how you’re feeling
tabs.content:
Don’t bottle up your emotions or put on a brave face. Talk to your family about any concerns you might have and discuss how they can support you now and after you get your exam results. You might like to ask them:

  • Are/were you worried about getting your exam results?
  • What impact did your grades have on your life and career?
  • Will you help me come up with plan B (e.g. research other apprenticeship/job/ study options)?
  • How will you feel if my grades aren’t what I/you hoped for?
  • Will you come with me to collect my results (or be available on the phone that day)?

Open up to your friends too and be there for them in return. They’re probably feeling just as overwhelmed and worried as you are so it’s important that you support each other over the next few weeks. Use Good Thinking's guide to looking out for your friends which contains tips on checking in and letting them know that you are there for them.

tabs.title: Celebrate your achievements whatever grades you get
tabs.content:
Whether you’re delighted or disappointed on results day, you should be really proud of everything you’ve achieved. After all the stress of studying, this is the time to celebrate with your friends and family.

Even if you don’t get the grades you want, it could lead to exciting new opportunities – whether that’s doing A Levels, a VTQ or NVQ, finding an apprenticeship or a job, doing a different university course or taking a gap year. Remember, your grades do not define you or your future!

Don’t feel pressured into sharing your exam results publicly if you don’t want to and try not to compare yourself to your friends or other people you follow on social media. Everyone has different strengths and weaknesses.

Of course, if you get your results and you don’t believe the correct process has been followed, you have the right to appeal or, if you don’t feel that your grade reflects your ability, you can choose to resit the exam. Talk to your teachers about the options available to you.

tabs.title: Get further support if you need it
tabs.content:
You can find a range of free wellbeing resources on Good Thinking, including

  • Clear Fear (app)
  • Feeling Good Teens (app)
  • Five ways to wellbeing (posters)
  • How to deal with stress (guide)
  • Looking out for your friends (guide)
  • Move Mood (app)
  • Results day: How to deal with anxiety, stress and imposter syndrome (blog)

Lots of other organisations offer advice and support to students ahead of results day. We recommend the following websites:

  • Childline
  • National Careers Service
  • stem4
  • The Mix
  • The Student Room
  • The Uni Guide
  • UCAS
  • YoungMinds

If you feel extremely distressed about your exam results, speak to your GP or call the 24/7 NHS mental health helpline in your borough. If you’re in immediate danger and it’s a medical emergency, call 999 straight away. Please don’t suffer alone – find out more here.

contentSections.content:
How do you feel about your body? Some days, you might feel happy and confident. Other days, you might worry about your appearance and how other people see you. For some people, the summer months are particularly difficult as they feel more self-conscious in summer clothes.

Body image is complex and can have a significant impact on mental wellbeing, contributing to anxiety, low mood, low self-esteem, loneliness and other common mental health concerns.

As the Mental Health Foundation says, “We convince ourselves that we should strive for perfection based on what we perceive around us, but we do know, realistically, no one is perfect. This leaves us feeling like we’re never enough. We’re always reaching for perfection, but we will never get there. This leads to an unhealthy body image, but working towards acceptance can lead to a healthier body image.”

In this blog, we share advice from the Good Thinking team to empower you to accept and love your body. As many young people struggle with body image, we also include some tips from young Londoners who are part of our Digital Health Ambassadors programme.

tabs.title: Signs of unhealthy body image
tabs.content:
Most of us worry about how we look from time to time – it’s human nature. However, certain behaviours could be a sign that you’re focusing too much on your body image, which can have a negative impact on your mental health.

  • Being preoccupied by your weight, shape or appearance (e.g. constantly checking in the mirror and weighing yourself).
  • Hiding your body or certain parts of your body.
  • Often comparing your body to other people’s bodies.
  • Calling yourself ‘fat’ or ‘ugly’ or using other negative words to describe your appearance.
  • Avoiding social events and activities where you’ll have to show your body (e.g. swimming).
  • Controlling what you eat and refusing certain foods.

tabs.title: Things that affect body image
tabs.content:
• Friends and family – comments about your body (either positive or negative) can have a big impact on your self-confidence.
  • Media – altered photos, adverts for weight loss and other body-related content can put pressure on you to over-examine and critique your own appearance.
  • Social media – whilst ‘body positive’ ambassadors are becoming more vocal on social media, there are still many influencers promoting “the perfect body”, which is unrealistic for most people. Remember, influencers are often paid by companies to promote products as part of marketing campaigns, or they’re sharing their own thoughts on body image. Don’t take these views as absolute facts.
  • Hormonal changes – puberty, menopause and other times of change can affect how you feel about your body.
  • Cultural norms – ethnic groups have different body ideals and different attitudes towards things such as weight.
  • Sexual orientation and gender identity – the LGBTQ+ community faces challenges that can affect body image, including societal expectations and experiences of stigma and discrimination.
  • Long-term health conditions – certain chronic illness can make you less confident in your body.
  • Past experiences – bullying or trauma related to your appearance can have a long-term effect.

tabs.title: How to be body positive
tabs.content:
• Appreciate your body – we’re all different! There is no right or wrong way to look. Our bodies are amazing, so consider all the amazing things it can do and make sure you look after it (focus on your health and wellbeing, not how you look).
  • Take control of your social media – don’t believe everything you see, unfollow any accounts that make you feel bad about your body, find positive role models and have regular time-outs.
  • Focus on your whole value – think about all your qualities, skills and strengths, not just what you look like.
  • Spend time with the right people – true friends say positive things about you and make you feel good about yourself (and you can do the same in return).
  • Challenge any negative thoughts – whenever you think “I look awful”, remind yourself how strong, healthy and kind you are.
  • Talk to someone you trust – if you’re struggling with body image, let a parent, sibling, friend or someone else know how you’re feeling so they can support you.

tabs.title: Tips from our Digital Health Ambassadors
tabs.content:
• Don’t trust everything that’s on social media.
  • Follow people on social media who are from the same walk of life as you – when you delete people who are promoting unrealistic standards, you’ll feel much better about yourself.
  • Surround yourself with good people who will encourage you and not bring you down.
  • Take a break from social media and concentrate on yourself.

results.title: Alcohol Awareness Week 2025: Healthy ways to manage work-related stress

metadata.description: Good Thinking marks Alcohol Awareness Week 2025 with a blog about healthy ways to manage work-related stress and boost wellbeing.
metadata.title: Alcohol Awareness Week 2025: Healthy ways to manage stress

contentSections.content:
Around 10 million people in the UK regularly drink alcohol in ways that can harm their health and wellbeing, according to the charity Alcohol Change UK. And it’s not just physical health that’s at risk, alcohol consumption can contribute to anxiety, low mood, sleep problems and other mental health conditions.

As Alcohol Change UK puts it, “From headaches, hangovers and sleepless nights to lower productivity and symptoms like anxiety and depression worsening over time, alcohol affects us in so many ways.”

The theme of this year’s Alcohol Awareness Week (7-13 July) is alcohol and work. Working is generally good for mental health as it provides routine, income, a sense of identity and connection with others. When under pressure at work, however, some people use alcohol as a coping mechanism.

In this blog, we recommend healthier ways to deal with work-related stress and generally boost your wellbeing. We also signpost to organisations that provide support for alcohol dependency.

You can find out more about Alcohol Awareness Week on the Alcohol Change UK website and by following @alcoholchangeuk and #AlcoholAwarenessWeek on social media.

tabs.title: Lowering stress
tabs.content:
Whatever you do for a living, there’ll be times when you feel stressed. It could be that your workload is too much or you’re not getting enough support from your manager. A colleague might be bullying you or you might worry that you’re at risk of redundancy. 

In these situations, your body’s natural reaction is to give you a rush of adrenaline. But if the feeling of stress lasts a while and is affecting your day-to-day life, it’s important to get help.

Read Good Thinking’s advice about managing stress, which includes symptoms of stress, types of stress, find the right help for you, free NHS-approved wellbeing apps and how to deal with stress.

tabs.title: Reducing anxiety
tabs.content:
It’s natural to be anxious or worried ahead of a big meeting or when you’re working on an important project. This anxiety might result in physical symptoms, such as headaches, irritability and finding it hard to sleep.

If you find that you’re feeling anxious a lot of the time, there is help available.

Read Good Thinking’s advice about reducing anxiety, which includes symptoms of anxiety, types of anxiety disorder, find the right help for you, free NHS-approved wellbeing apps and how to deal with uncertainty.

tabs.title: Boosting mood
tabs.content:
Things happen at work that can have a negative effect on your mood. Perhaps you work on your own or have just started a new role and feel lonely. Or you might not be enjoying your job or feel like you’re not progressing as quickly as you’d like.

If you have persistent low mood and it’s making everything feel really difficult, it’s time to get some support. 

Read Good Thinking’s advice about boosting mood, which includes symptoms of mood disorders, types of mood disorders, find the right help for you, free NHS-approved wellbeing apps and depression workbook.

tabs.title: Improving sleep
tabs.content:
Getting enough sleep is one of the most important things you can do for your physical and mental health. But what if you’re struggling to sleep because you’re worried about work? Or if you do night shifts and can’t get into the right sleep pattern?

Fortunately, there are lots of things you can do to help you get to sleep and stay asleep. 

Read Good Thinking’s advice about improving sleep, which includes symptoms of sleep disorder, types of sleep disorder, find the right help for you, free NHS-approved wellbeing apps and sleep workbook.

tabs.title: Supporting others
tabs.content:
If a relative, friend or colleague is experiencing work-related stress, you can make a big difference by offering your support – but it can be hard to know what to do.

Our quick guides to supporting others are a great place to start – they contain advice on how to spot the signs and symptoms of mental ill health in others, how to check in on someone and how to help them get the support they need.

If you know someone who has become dependent on alcohol, you might be interested in reading Sarah Drage’s guest blog for Good Thinking. We also recommend Alcohol Change UK’s advice for family and friends.

results.title: Loneliness Awareness Week 2025:  Tackling social isolation across London
results.subtitle: It’s not always easy to connect with others in a big city – but there is lots of help available from Good Thinking and other organisations.

metadata.description: To mark Loneliness Awareness Week 2025, Good Thinking looks at eight London initiatives that are helping to tackle social isolation and boost mental health.
metadata.title: Loneliness Awareness Week 2025

contentSections.content:
What do you think of when you hear the word ‘lonely’? Is it something you’ve experienced yourself? How did you cope with it and move forward?

Sometimes we all feel lonely. In a huge city like London, it can often feel counter intuitive to experience a sense of isolation. Despite being surrounded by millions of people every day, building and maintaining those important connections with family, friends or colleagues can be surprisingly difficult.

There’s no shame in admitting to feeling lonely, and this Loneliness Awareness Week (9-15 June) is all about reducing the stigma associated with this natural human emotion.

It’s estimated that 1 in 12 Londoners experience loneliness, which can have a significant impact on mental health and wellbeing, exacerbating stress, anxiety and low mood. Perhaps you’ve moved to London recently and don’t know many people yet. Maybe you’ve lost a partner or close friend and are really missing them. Or you might be facing discrimination and feeling excluded from society.

When we asked our Digital Health Ambassadors (aged 16-25) what their advice would be for any young person who is feeling lonely, the most common tip was to talk to someone you trust. As one of them said, “Talk to a friend about it… maybe someone you can trust with opening up to and just venting on how you’re feeling. That might really help with feelings of loneliness.”

With loneliness sometimes leading to low mood, anxiety, stress, sleep problems and other mental health concerns, it’s important that you take action and get the right support.

In this article, we look at some initiatives that are helping Londoners to tackle loneliness and isolation at all ages and stages of life.

Our guide to the five ways to good mental wellbeing might also be useful if you’re feeling lonely. It contains tips on how to connect with other people, be physically active, learn new skills, give to others and pay attention to the present moment.

For updates about what’s going on during Loneliness Awareness Week, visit the website and follow @marmalade_trust on social media.

tabs.title: Good Thinking Small Grants Programme: London Borough of Newham
tabs.content:
In 2024, Good Thinking supported 10 community organisations across the London Borough of Newham to develop initiatives designed to improve mental health and wellbeing across the patch through the provision of small pots of funding. Through the programme, organisations were trained as Good Thinking ‘super users’ to be confident in championing and sharing the wide range of mental health and wellbeing resources available through the Good Thinking platform with members of the community.

Aishah Help

Aishah Help is a non-profit, women-led organisation in the London Borough of Newham that supports disadvantaged communities to achieve their personal, social and economic potential. Through participation in Good Thinking’s Small Grants Programme, Aishah Help organised two befriending events that addressed social isolation among older adults by creating opportunities for meaningful social interactions, particularly through inter-generational activities to help promote inclusivity and support participants to rebuild their confidence, resilience and sense of purpose.

Read more


Alternatives Trust East London

Alternatives Trust East is a small charity that empowers vulnerable families in the London Borough of Newham to transform their lives. The charity provides a range of services, including advocacy to address the causes of poverty, practical help, one-to-one parenting support, counselling and therapeutic support. 

Through training as Good Thinking ‘super users’, Alternatives staff enabling built confidence to share mental health and wellbeing resources with service users across a range of forums, including weekly Family Hub social events and individual counselling sessions.

Read more


Inspire Women, Men and Children

Inspire UK works with BAME communities in East London (Newham and Tower Hamlets) as well as migrants and refugees arriving in the UK by providing targeted, culturally sensitive and holistic support services to meet their needs. Through the Small Grants Programme, Inspire adopted a multi-channel approach to community engagement, using culturally tailored approaches and collaborating with trusted community leaders and organisations to reach the diverse communities of Newham.

One participant said that Inspire “really made me feel like I wasn’t alone in this journey”.

Read more

tabs.title: Good Gym
tabs.content:
GoodGym is a unique community of runners, walkers and cyclists who combine getting fit with doing good. From planting trees at local parks to cleaning up community centres and helping older people in the community with things like maintenance and gardening, GoodGym has over 25,000 members across London and beyond. It’s an opportunity to connect with others, reduce isolation and loneliness in the community and make a difference.

Read more

tabs.title: South East London Mind's ‘Mindful Mums’ network
tabs.content:
These award-winning, free wellbeing groups in Bromley, Lewisham, Greenwich, Lambeth and Southwark help pregnant women and new mothers to look after their mental and emotional health during pregnancy and their baby’s first year. It’s about taking time out to make meaningful connections, de-stress and meet others going through a similar experience to talk and reduce feelings of isolation.

Read more

tabs.title: The Great Friendship Project
tabs.content:
The Great Friendship Project supports young adults through campaigns, research, support and fun activities, including social walks, board game events and nights out. With a community of 43,000 people across the UK, 73% of attendees say that the project has helped to reduce social isolation.

Read our interview with David Gradon, founder of The Great Friendship Project

tabs.title: West Central London Mind’s Community Living Well Peer Support Network
tabs.content:
This network helps residents of Kensington and Chelsea to reduce isolation, make new connections and access support based on their own personal and shared experiences of mental health concerns.

Daisy Petrow of WCL Mind, describes it as “a welcoming space where residents can connect with others, share experiences and find mutual support”.

Read more

metadata.description: Want to quit smoking? Stop Smoking London and Good Thinking provide advice to help you quit and stay calm in the process.
metadata.title: How to quit smoking and boost your mental health

attributes.alternativeText: Good Thinking and Stop Smoking London stay calm poster
attributes.name: Quit_smoking_and_stay_calm.width-500.jpg

contentSections.content:
There are many reasons why people smoke. Perhaps you do it when you’re out with friends or when you’re bored. Or you might feel that it helps you to relax when you’re feeling anxious or stressed. 

If you stop smoking, you’ll see immediate benefits – for both your physical and mental health. In this article, Stop Smoking London and Good Thinking have teamed up to give you some tips on how to quit and how to stay calm in the process.

1. Understand the role anxiety plays in smoking

We know it can be hard to stop smoking and it may feel especially difficult when you’re feeling anxious or stressed. 

Anxiety and smoking are inter-connected: if you're feeling anxious, you might turn to smoking as a coping mechanism. However, smoking can exacerbate anxiety and create a cycle of dependence.

Smoking just relieves nicotine withdrawal symptoms like irritability and low mood, tricking you into believing it helps with anxiety and stress.

It's proven that people who stop smoking have less anxiety, depression and stress, as well as improved mood, compared to those who continue to smoke.

2. Use meditation and deep breathing to help reduce anxiety and stress

A great way to feel calmer as you stop smoking is to use established guided meditation or mindfulness techniques. This can not only make you feel relaxed but may help you to make other healthy lifestyle choices.

Good Thinking has a range of useful free apps that you can download, including Meditainment and Be Mindful. You could also follow the steps in the Mindfulness Workbook by the Centre for Clinical Interventions to help improve your mental wellbeing.

3. Make a quit plan

By giving yourself time to prepare, you can move forward with your stop smoking journey with confidence. Talk to your GP or local stop smoking service about Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT) products, which provide nicotine without the harmful chemicals in tobacco, alleviating cravings and withdrawal symptoms. they come in various forms like patches, gum, lozenges, inhalers, and nasal sprays. 

Some medications are available on prescription to greatly increase your chances of successfully stopping for good.

You’re three times as likely to stop smoking successfully with support from a local stop smoking service. Find details of your local Stop Smoking Service here.

It also helps to be prepared for those situations and feelings that may make you want to smoke. Visit Stop Smoking London for tools and resources to support you in making a quit plan.

4. Get plenty of sleep

Sleep disturbances are a common side effect of nicotine withdrawal. And lack of sleep can make everything, including quitting smoking, feel so much harder. So, it’s particularly important to get on top of any sleep problems you may encounter quickly.

For advice on how to get a good night’s sleep as you quit smoking, check out Good Thinking’s Sleep Workbook. It contains a programme of six modules, which you can use at a time and place that suits you.

5. Take regular exercise

Exercising for 30 minutes a day is a great self-care practice to get your endorphins flowing and boost your energy. 

As you quit smoking, you may notice that your lungs heal and you have less coughing and shortness of breath, making it easier to exercise. Being more active will also boost your mood, reduce stress and help you sleep better.

Do you know all the benefits of quitting smoking? Take a look at Stop Smoking London’s information on the many benefits of quitting smoking .

6. Don’t do it alone, ask for help

Our final tip is to pay attention to how you feel and be compassionate with these feelings. It may help you to speak about these with your family and friends. There are also online communities to help you quit smoking and Stop Smoking London’s friendly telephone advisors are just a call away.

If you would like help at any stage of your stop smoking journey, visit the Stop Smoking London website, You can also find details of your local Stop Smoking Service here.

If you're concerned about your own mental health (or someone else’s wellbeing), a good place to start is to contact your GP. You can also get expert advice from a number of specialist helplines.

results.title: Life can be stressful – be kind to yourself
results.subtitle: To mark Stress Awareness Month 2025, Good Thinking suggests four techniques to help reduce stress and improve mental wellbeing.

metadata.description: To mark Stress Awareness Month, London’s digital mental wellbeing service Good Thinking publishes a new blog about reducing stress.
metadata.title: Stress Awareness Month 2025

contentSections.content:
April is #StressAwarenessMonth, a time to encourage open conversations about the impact of stress and explore new ways to cope. This year, the theme is #LeadWithLove, which promotes approaching ourselves and others with kindness, compassion and acceptance to help reduce stress and improve overall mental wellbeing.

When faced with danger, your body’s natural reaction is to give you a rush of adrenaline (often called the ‘fight or flight’ response). This feeling of stress is perfectly normal. It might happen ahead of a job interview, exam or important meeting or when you’re stuck in traffic. You might feel stressed about the cost of living or political uncertainties around the world. Or you might be experiencing relationship problems or health worries.

In some cases, stress can be a motivator, but if it’s having a negative impact on your daily life and your health, Good Thinking is here to help.

We’ve got a broad range of resources to help Londoners deal with feelings of stress. In this article for #StressAwarenessMonth, you’ll find three techniques to help you reduce stress and one to help you #LeadWithLove and support someone you know.

You can find out more about Stress Awareness Month on the Stress Management Society website.

tabs.title: Focus on what you can control
tabs.content:
Dr Russ Harris, author of The Happiness Trap, suggests there is something simple that you can do to reduce stress: “...the single most useful thing anyone can do in any type of crisis… is to focus on what’s in your control.”

  • Find something small you can do, such as cooking a meal, going for a walk or listening to a podcast.
  • Don’t measure the size of the activity, simply complete it.
  • Allow yourself to have a sense of achievement for completing the activity

You might also find it helpful to write down all the things you’re worried about, then divide them into two categories: ‘What I can control’ and ‘What I can’t control’. For the things in the second category, it’s important to recognise that, whilst you can’t control the action, you do have control over how you react.

For example:

  • You can’t control rising utility bills but you can check whether a new tariff might save you money
  • You can’t control how someone at work treats you but you can decide how you respond to that person
  • You can’t control your train running late but you can choose to enjoy an extra few minutes reading your book or listening to music

tabs.title: Deal with uncertainty
tabs.content:
The APPLE technique is a useful thought process to follow when you feel anxious or worried.

  • Acknowledge – Notice and acknowledge the uncertainty when it comes to mind.
  • Pause – Don't react to the uncertainty. Just take a moment to pause and breathe.
  • Pull back – Tell yourself that this is just the worry talking. This apparent need for certainty is not helpful or necessary. It's only a thought or feeling, not a fact.
  • Let go – Let go of the thought or feeling. It will pass. You don't need to respond to it. Perhaps imagine it floating away in a bubble or cloud.
  • ﻿Explore – At this present moment, everything is OK. Notice your breathing, focus on what you can see, hear and touch right now. Then shift your focus of attention to something else, like what you were doing before you started to worry.

tabs.title: Pay attention to the present moment
tabs.content:
When you feel overwhelmed and stressed, paying attention to the present moment can help. Often called ‘mindfulness’, here are a few techniques you could try:

  • Notice the small everyday things, like the smell of your morning coffee or the sound of your child's laughter
  • Go for a walk and tune in to all your senses – what can you see, hear, smell, touch, taste?
  • Take regular micropauses throughout the day – for 30 seconds, sit in silence and focus only on your breathing and the sensations in your body

Listen to the Good Thinking podcast in which mindfulness trainer and consultant psychologist Janet Wingrove explains how a micropause can help your mental health and check out the free NHS-approved wellbeing apps, including Be Mindful and Meditainment.

tabs.title: Support someone you know
tabs.content:
In challenging times, it’s important to be kind and look out for those around you. These three simple steps will help you to support your family, friends and colleagues.

  • Step 1: Spot the signs and symptoms – do they seem worried, overwhelmed or unhappy? Are they experiencing physical symptoms, such as headaches? Have they become more distant than usual?
  • Step 2: Check in and let them know you care – ask them how they’re feeling and create a safe and supportive space for them to open up. If they’re reluctant to talk, reassure them that you’re there for them if they ever want a chat.
  • Step 3: Help them to get the support they need – Good Thinking provides lots of advice and tools but they might also benefit from talking to their GP, making a self-referral to an NHS Talking Therapies service, contacting a mental health charity or calling their local NHS mental health helpline.

You can find more detailed descriptions of these three steps in Good Thinking's quick guides for supporting others.

metadata.title: How to stay mentally healthy at university

contentSections.content:
University can be an exciting time. Indeed, for many young people, it’s almost become a rite of passage – a steppingstone to learning, development and growth in the transition to adult life.

However, it’s also a time of significant change for many young people, be it moving away from home for the first time, navigating to build new ‘life’ skills or forming new friendship groups. For some, these changes can be overwhelming, and it’s perfectly normal to feel anxious, stressed or low. According to a 2022 survey by charity Student Minds, over half of respondents self-reported a mental health concern, with over a quarter stating they had a diagnosed mental health condition.

Whether you’re a fresher who has lost their confidence or a final year student who is worried about the job market, finding the right advice and guidance to support your mental wellbeing is vital. With the cost of living soaring, you might also be feeling stressed about your finances – indeed, research by the National Union of Students (NUS) in July 2022 showed that one in three students in the UK has less than £50 a month left in their pocket after paying rent and bills.

Our toolkit for students contains recommendations for free NHS-approved mental wellbeing apps, including Student Health App, Clear Fear and Combined Minds, as well as links to expert advice on a wide range of student-related topics.

We hope you find this toolkit useful and, don’t forget, you can contact your university’s wellbeing, welfare and finance services to discuss any particular concerns. You can also get in touch with Shout (text STUDENT to 85258) or Samaritans (call 116 123 or email jo@samaritans.org). If you need urgent help, you can find details of support organisations on Good Thinking’s Urgent Support page.

tabs.title: Top tips
tabs.content:
1. Stay connected – make the most of opportunities to meet new people (e.g. through clubs and societies) and have fun with your friends. Stay in touch with your family via phone calls, texts and video chat and be honest about how you’re feeling so that they can support you. You might also find it useful to join an online community, such as The Student Room, where you can share your experiences with other students.
  2. Be physically active – whether you walk, run, cycle, go to the gym or join a university sports club, being active is great for your mental wellbeing too. You might also like to try some workouts on YouTube or download a fitness app to keep you on track. If you’re doing any of your learning virtually or spending lots of time studying at a desk, make sure you schedule time for fresh air and exercise breaks.
  3. Learn something new each day – of course, you’ll be learning lots of new stuff on your course but why not see if there are any clubs or societies you could join? Art, debating, football, geology, photography, Spanish, windsurfing... there's something for everyone. You could also take this time to teach yourself a new skill, like how to cook a meal you’ve not tried before.
  4. Give to others – acts of kindness don’t only help other people, they can also give you a feeling of purpose. It can be as simple as asking a friend how they are and spending some time with them. If any of your friends are feeling anxious or stressed, you can use the free Combined Minds app to support them. You might also like to volunteer for a local charity or take part in a fundraising campaign that your university is running.
  5. Pay attention to the present moment – being aware of your thoughts and the world around you can help to improve your mental wellbeing. If you feel frustrated that your school, college or university experience is different to how you wanted it to be, you might like to download a mindfulness or meditation app.

For more information, read our five ways to good mental wellbeing article. We've also started producing wellbeing guides for different faith and belief communities – check them out here.

tabs.title: Need practical support?
tabs.content:
Going to university is very exciting but it can also be nerve-racking, especially if you’ve never lived away from home or if you have money worries. Indeed, a recent survey by The Student Room found that more than a fifth (21%) of university students say they need support for life skills (e.g. cooking, cleaning and laundry) and 16% want advice on money management.

To help you deal with the practicalities and worry less, the Good Thinking team has put together a list of links to useful websites and also created a checklist to help you decide what to pack for university and a checklist to help you deal with money worries at university .

tabs.title: Feeling anxious?
tabs.content:
You might be feeling anxious about starting at, or going back to, university. This might include how you'll keep up with your studies, manage your finances or make new friends. tabs.title: Having trouble sleeping?
tabs.content:
If you’re struggling to get to sleep or waking in the night, you’re not alone – around a third of adults have trouble sleeping at some point in their lives. Rest and relaxation is really important for both your physical and mental health so Good Thinking provides a range of resources to support you in your quest for a good night’s sleep.

metadata.description: To mark World Sleep Day 2025, Good Thinking looks at the connection between sleep and mental health and signposts to resources for Londoners.
metadata.title: Why you should make sleep health a priority

contentSections.content:
We’ve all had those occasional nights spent tossing and turning, unable to switch off and get to sleep. However, when sleep problems become more regular, they can be both a cause and effect of poor mental health.

Created by the World Sleep Society, #WorldSleepDay (14 March) promotes the importance of sleep for health and wellbeing and encourages everyone to make sleep an priority.

Dr. Lourdes Del Rosso co-chairs World Sleep Day and, says,

“Waking up feeling fully rested is one of the greatest sensations in the world. Imagine how energising that feels – your mind refreshed, your body recharged and your resilience stronger than ever. Prioritising your sleep health is the key to maintaining that energy and thriving every day!”

Your sleep will be influenced by different external factors at different times in your life. Maybe you’re a new parent adapting to a new nighttime routine, or perhaps your job involves shift work making it challenging to develop a regular sleeping pattern. Perhaps playing games online or scrolling through social media keeps you up at night. Or worrying about money, work or your health might make it difficult to fall asleep.

For Londoners, the noise and lights of a busy, 24-hour city can make nodding off particularly difficult for many people.

As London’s digital mental wellbeing service, Good Thinking understands the close connection between sleep and mental health. In this article, we examine why sleep is so important, explain what healthy sleep is and suggest ways to make your sleep health a priority. And, of course, we direct you to the most useful Good Thinking resources to help you get a good night’s sleep.

For more information about World Sleep Day, visit the official website.

tabs.title: Why is sleep so important for your health and wellbeing?
tabs.content:
In the same way that nutrition and physical activity are critical for your health, so too is sleep. While you’re sleeping, your body is busy repairing cells, resetting hormones and allowing muscles to rest that have all been used throughout the day. Regular poor sleep can disrupt this regeneration process, potentially placing you at increased risk of a range of health conditions, such as obesity, cardiovascular disease, infection and diabetes.

On a mental level, sleep gives you time to process the information you took in during the day and lay down memories. Unhealthy sleep behaviours and tiredness can impact your mental health, for example, by developing or worsening anxiety, depression and loneliness. It can also be a bit of a vicious cycle, with mental health conditions, such as stress, in turn affecting your sleep.

In the sleep workbook that she developed for Good Thinking, Cognitive Behavioural Psychotherapist Majella Cogan notes that most people will have trouble sleeping at some point in their lives. In fact, around a third of adults experience difficulties with their sleep.

tabs.title: What exactly is healthy sleep?
tabs.content:
We all need different amounts of sleep but, as a general rule, adults should aim for seven or eight hours of sleep each night.

Sleep health is more complicated than simply the amount of sleep you get, however. Healthy sleep behaviours include the efficiency of your sleep (i.e. how easily you fall asleep and stay asleep), timing (i.e. what time of day you sleep), regularity (i.e. whether you go to sleep and wake up at similar times every day), how alert you feel when you’re awake and how satisfied you feel with the quality of your sleep.

Michael Farquhar, Consultant in Paediatric Sleep Medicine at Guy's & St Thomas' NHS Trust, noted in a Good Thinking podcast that, “A lot of sleep is about consistency and routine – so, setting a consistent bedtime routine but also trying to stick to a consistent wake time.”

“The time before going to bed is often really important,” he adds, “We all need to have things that help us to relax and wind down.”

tabs.title: How can you prioritise sleep health?
tabs.content:
If you’re looking for some quick tips, take a look at Good Thinking’s guide to getting better sleep, which covers three common questions and three top tips.

If you’re really struggling to sleep and are happy to put some time and effort in, our sleep workbook is a great place to start. It’s made up of six modules that will help you to improve your sleep, namely:

  1. Understanding your sleep problem – do you have a specific sleep disorder?
  2. Setting realistic sleep expectations – what is normal sleep?
  3. Sleep hygiene and relaxation – what lifestyle habits and environmental factors affect your sleep?
  4. Developing a new sleep schedule – how can you improve the bed-sleep connection?
  5. Thinking and sleep – what can you do quieten your mind at 2am?
  6. Maintaining progress – how can you stay on track?

Majella Cogan acknowledges that “improving sleep will take time and persistence”. But thanks to the tips and practical exercises in the Good Thinking workbook, including a sleep diary, night-time routine checklist and sleep plan, you should “begin to notice improvements to your general wellbeing as well as your sleep”.

metadata.title: Children's Mental Health Week 2025

contentSections.content:
Organised by the charity Place2Be, this year’s Children’s Mental Health Week (3-9 February) aims to encourage children, teenagers and adults to embrace self-awareness and explore what it means to them so they can grow and develop resilience, as well as set an example for future generations.

With the theme being ‘Know yourself, grow yourself’, Place2Be says, “The more we understand about ourselves, the better we're prepared to tackle life's ups and downs. During Children’s Mental Health Week, we want to celebrate children and young people building resilience, embracing self-awareness and forming strong connections with others.”

Our own conversations with Good Thinking's Digital Health Ambassadors (aged 16 to 25) have shown that young people are very aware of how their behaviour changes when they feel anxious, stressed or overwhelmed.

“I’m quite quiet and I’ll distance myself from my friend group,” said one young person, whilst another told us, “I’m not good at telling other people how I’m feeling and looking for help.”

In recent years, we’ve developed a series of guides to help Londoners, including young people, support others who might be struggling with their mental health (see link below). So, we also asked the DHAs about how they start conversations with their friends.

One young person suggested “A simple ‘how are you?’, checking up, maybe in a text message if you don’t want to say it face to face” is a good starting point. Another noted the importance of giving friends a safe space to talk. As they said, “Even just letting them know, I’m here any time you need me. If and when you’re ready to open up, feel free to come to me.”

Of course, parents, carers, teachers, health and care professionals and other adults play a vital role in helping children and young people to understand themselves better and become more resilient.

Here at Good Thinking, we provide a wide range of resources to help adults support children and young people (see links below). Our partners at Thrive LDN also offer resources for schools and, to mark Children’s Mental Health Week 2025, they have launched a new framework for health and care professionals who may be supporting families following a traumatic bereavement. 

 

Want to get involved with Children’s Mental Health Week? Follow #ChildrensMentalHealthWeek on social media and at @Place2BeCharity on Facebook and @_Place2Be on Instagram

We all need community and connection. So, on Friday 31 January, Great Mental Health Day (#GreatMentalHealth) will get people across London talking about their mental health and wellbeing and help to raise awareness of the brilliant local support services and resources available to Londoners all year round.

When times are tough, it’s really important that we look after our own wellbeing. But we also need to support other people so that they know they are not alone.

Great Mental Health Day has been described by Londoners as having “opened up the conversation of mental health” and as “an amazing opportunity to learn about how to access services we hadn’t heard of before”.

Now in its fourth year and organised by Thrive LDN, the theme of Great Mental Health Day is ‘small actions for others’. To help you, the Good Thinking team has put together a list of things you can do to support your friends, relatives, colleagues and other people in your community.

There are lots of events and activities (both in-person and virtual) happening on the day. Here at Good Thinking, we’re hosting a free webinar at 1pm on Friday 31 January and would love you to join us.

Wherever you live in London, why not spread some hope and kindness on Great Mental Health Day?

tabs.title: Small actions you can do for others

Based on the five ways to good mental wellbeing, here are 15 suggestions for small actions that will make a big difference to other people.

  1. Call one of your friends or relatives
  2. Organise a get-together for your wider family
  3. Do some shopping for an elderly neighbour
  4. Go for a weekend walk with a friend
  5. Get some mates together for a class at your local leisure centre
  6. Ask a friend or colleague how they are (and really listen to their answer)
  7. Volunteer for a local charity or community organisation
  8. Take an evening class with a friend
  9. Send a message or email to someone you’ve not spoken to for a while
  10. Donate some groceries to a local food bank
  11. Arrange a bike ride with your family or a group of friends
  12. Set up a hobby club (e.g. a book club, a sewing group or a cooking club)
  13. Talk to your kids about why it’s so important to be in the present moment
  14. Help a friend or relative with a DIY project
  15. Download a yoga or meditation app for you and a friend to do together

You might also like to download Good Thinking’s quick guides for supporting others, which include advice on how to spot the signs of mental ill health in someone else and how to help them get the support they need.

results.subtitle:
Struggling with the cost of living? Dreading your commute? Feeling isolated and lonely? London is an amazing place to live and work but it has its challenges. 

To mark Stress Awareness Week (4-8 November), the Good Thinking team is offering tips to help you cope with the pressures of life in the capital.

metadata.description: To mark Stress Awareness Week (4-8 November), the Good Thinking team is offering tips to help you cope with the pressures of life in the capital.
metadata.title: Stress Awareness Week 2024

contentSections.content:
Organised by the International Stress Management Association (ISMA) UK, #StressAwarenessWeek is an annual event dedicated to stress management and combating the stigma of stress and mental health issues.

Whilst stress is a perfectly normal reaction to a threat (it prepares you for ‘fight or flight’), it becomes something quite different when you face ongoing threats and challenges. The most helpful thing to remember is to focus on what you can do – a behaviour you’re in control of.

Here are some of our top tips for dealing with everyday worries, reducing stress and boosting your wellbeing.

tabs.title: Cost of living
tabs.content:
London is one of the most expensive cities in the world. Along with high housing costs, the cost of living remains a worry for many Londoners, but there are some things you can do to help you cope with financial pressures.

  • Create a household budget planner and shop around to see if you can reduce any regular bills.
  • Talk to someone you trust – they might be going through something similar and you could support each other.
  • Remember that life is always uncertain – worrying about the worst-case scenario won’t change the outcome!
  • Get help if you’re struggling with your finances (we provide links to support organisations at the end of this article).

tabs.title: Fast pace
tabs.content:
London has a fantastic energy – there’s so much to do and see – but what if the fast pace of life in the city starts to feel too much?

  • Be kind to yourself by prioritising exercise, self-care and sleep.
  •  Make a conscious decision to do less – it’s OK to say no to extra work or social activities if you simply don’t have the time or head space.
  • Learn some breathing exercises to lower your stress levels.
  • Connect with nature whenever possible – go for a walk in your local park or, if you have some outside space at home, do some gardening.

tabs.title: Long working hours
tabs.content:
According to the Office for National Statistics, eight of the 10 places in England with the longest work weeks are in London. Here’s our advice for avoiding burnout in the workplace.

  • Establish some boundaries, such as leaving the office at a certain time and not responding to emails in the evenings.
  • Focus on creating a good work-life balance – make time for hobbies and seeing friends, always use your annual leave, and try to get enough sleep.
  • Take short breaks throughout the day and a proper lunch break (head outside, go to the gym, eat a healthy lunch).
  • If your workload is unmanageable, talk to your manager – they might be able to help you prioritise your tasks, delegate work to colleagues, and offer time management training.
  • If you’re struggling at work and it’s getting you down, find out what wellbeing support is available for employees (this might include support from Mental Health First Aiders or an employee assistance programme that offers a free helpline)

tabs.title: complex commutes
tabs.content:
With Londoners’ average journey time to work taking 47 minutes, how can you improve your commute?

  • Switch up your journey – could you take the bus rather than the tube or travel outside of rush hour?
  • Listen to your favourite playlist (research shows that music can help to reduce anxiety).
  • Learn something new by reading a book or listening to a podcast.
  • Focus on your thoughts and feelings – you might like to download a mindfulness or meditation app (we link to free NHS-approved apps available to Good Thinking users at the end of this article).
  • Incorporate physical exercise into your commute – could you walk some of the way or start cycling to work?

tabs.title: Loneliness
tabs.content:
Research by the Campaign to End Loneliness shows that 1 in 12 Londoners experience loneliness. Here are a few things you can do to connect with new people and feel less isolated.

•  Arrange to see friends and family whenever you can and stay in touch in between.

•  Be physically active – could you join your local leisure centre or take part in Parkrun?

•  Sign up for a course so you can meet new people and learn new skills.

•  Volunteer for a local charity – giving to others will have a positive effect on you too.

•  Join a community group, such as The Great London Friendship Project.

metadata.description: Good Thinking offers top tips to help you move more to boost your mental wellbeing in time for Mental Health Awareness Week 2024.
metadata.title: How to move more to boost your mental health

contentSections.content:
Each year, millions of people come together to promote good mental health during #MentalHealthAwarenessWeek. Loneliness, kindness and body image have been the focus of previous awareness weeks and, this year, the theme is ‘Movement: Moving more for our mental health’. 

Physical exercise is one of the five ways to good mental wellbeing as it has so many benefits – from improving mood to lowering stress, increasing self-esteem to helping with sleep problems. In this blog by the Good Thinking team, we provide lots of tips to help you incorporate more movement into your daily life.

tabs.title: Do what works for you
tabs.content:
The NHS recommends that adults should do some kind of physical activity every day. But that doesn’t have to mean going for a run or joining a gym – you can start small and build up over time. 

Perhaps you could go for a short walk each day? Do some seated exercises at home? Or take a free online yoga class? 

The most important thing is to find something that you enjoy doing and to do it regularly. If you’ve not exercised for a while, you may want to speak to your GP first.

tabs.title: Get into the habit
tabs.content:
You might need some help making exercise a regular habit. 

It’s a good idea to set yourself a realistic goal and pair it with something you already do every day. For example, your goal might be ‘I’ll get off the tube one stop early and walk the last few minutes to work’ or ‘I’ll go for a bike ride after I’ve dropped the kids at school’.

Then repeat, repeat, repeat until it starts to happen naturally. Find out more in our articles about Developing healthy new habits and Establishing a routine.

tabs.title: Move with others
tabs.content:
One way to help you stick to your movement goals is to team up with other people. If you arrange to meet a friend for a walk or an exercise class, you’re more likely to do it. And social connection is also really good for your mental health so it’s a win win! 

When our friends at Thrive LDN organised a Walk Talk Walk event earlier this year, everyone really enjoyed meeting new people whilst walking along the River Thames. 

There are lots of organisations around London that offer social walks, runs and other activities. Check out our interview with The Great London Friendship Project, read Thrive LDN's blog about parkrun and visit the Run Talk Run, Sport in Mind and Walk + Talk websites.

tabs.title: Spend time outdoors
tabs.content:
Seven out of 10 UK adults say that being close to nature improves their mood so, if you get outside to exercise, you’ll get the benefits of movement plus the benefits of fresh air and green spaces! 

You might like to go for a walk or bike ride in one of London’s parks or along a river or canal path. Or you could do some gardening or get involved in a park cleanup. 

Take a look at our article about Connecting with nature for more ideas.

tabs.title: Stay motivated
tabs.content:
Even if you get off to a good start with your movement goals, you might lose interest over time or simply find that life gets in the way. 

To help you stay motivated and track your activity, why not download an app such as Feeling Good or NHS Couch to 5k? 

You could also keep a note of your progress and write down how exercising makes you feel (read our blog about journaling) or get involved with the Mental Health Foundation’s Around the World challenge on Strava in May.

tabs.title: Get enough sleep
tabs.content:
Good sleep is essential for good health and wellbeing. As a general rule, adults need 7-8 hours sleep and, when you exercise regularly, you need to make sure you get enough rest. 

You can find lots of great tips in our Sleep workbook, such as keeping a sleep diary, having a good bedtime routine and improving your sleep hygiene. 

If you think that mindfulness could help you to relax, you can download the Be Mindful app for free.

contentSections.content:
Bright frosty mornings, cooking a hearty meal, staying in to watch your favourite TV series… these are just a few things you might enjoy in the winter. But this time of year also brings its challenges. Shorter days and colder temperatures can affect your mood, feelings of loneliness can be heightened at this time of year, and with the cost of living continuing to rise, you might be worried about paying your bills.

London’s digital mental wellbeing service, Good Thinking, is here to support you all year round. In this article, you’ll find information about dealing with your finances, staying connected with friends and family and coping with possible changes in mood during the winter months. We hope you find it useful and would encourage you to reach out for help if you need it.

tabs.title: Worried about money?
tabs.content:
With food prices and household bills remaining high, many Londoners are feeling the pinch. In fact, around 400,000 households in London are affected by fuel poverty and The Felix Project estimates that one in four working parents in London struggle to feed their families. 

As Matt Dronfield, Managing Director of Debt Free Advice, commented last year, “As winter approaches, over a quarter of our clients are burdened by utility bill debt, facing the agonizing choice between keeping warm and putting food on the table. Around 1 in 5 clients are also experiencing mental health issues due to their debt. Reach out to the free available services in your area as early as possible if you’re worried about your finance and wellbeing."

If you’re finding it stressful staying on top of your finances, you might find the steps below helpful:

  • Focus on what you can control – if you find you are spending lots of time thinking about what the energy companies or politicians are doing, instead try to focus on the small things you can achieve personally. These might be practical (like changing your energy tariff) or fun (like going for a walk with a friend).
  • Ask for help – money worries can affect your mental health and, at the same time, your mental health can affect how you manage your finances so it’s important that you ask for help when you need it (we’ve put together a list of support organisations below).
  • Be kind to yourself – make sure your daily routine includes enjoyable and rewarding activities and that you prioritise exercise, self-care and sleep.


Use the following Good Thinking resource to boost your mental wellbeing and get practical advice on dealing with money worries:

  • The rising cost of living: How to look after your mental health


For advice and support available in London from the Greater London Authority:

  • Greater London Authority (Help with the cost of living)


For help managing your finances or dealing with debt, we recommend the following websites:

  • Citizens Advice - advice on getting help with the cost of living
  • Debt Free Advice (0800 808 5700) - free, expert advice to individuals with problem debt
  • Energy Advice London (0808 196 8260) - free advice on saving energy and money
  • Money Helper - free guidance from the Money & Pensions Service
  • StepChange - free debt advice
  • UK Government (Cost of Living Payments) - guidance on getting extra payments to help with the cost of living if you’re entitled to certain benefits or tax credits
  • UK Government (Household Support Fund) - help with the cost of living from your local council

tabs.title: Feeling lonely?
tabs.content:
A study for the Mayor of London revealed that one in 12 Londoners (around 700,000 people) are often or always lonely and that Londoners are more likely than people in other parts of the UK to be affected by loneliness. If you spent the festive season on your own or you simply can't afford to go out and socialise, feelings of isolation and sadness might increase.

If you’re feeling lonely, try to incorporate the five ways to good mental wellbeing in your life: 

  • Connect with other people – check in with friends and family and stay in touch via phone, text, email and video chat. If you’d like to meet new people, how about joining a local community group or befriending network?
  • Be physically active – whether you walk, run, cycle or do something else, exercise has many benefits for your mental health… and, even more so, if you exercise with a friend or in a group.
  • Learn something new – could you sign up for a course or join a local club? You’ll not only learn something new but meet new people too.  
  • Give to others – supporting other people can also help to make you happy so perhaps you could volunteer for a local charity or offer to help one of your neighbours?
  • Pay attention to the present moment – slowing down and being more mindful can help you to understand yourself better and enjoy life more. 


Make the most of the following Good Thinking resources to help you connect with others:

  • Five ways to good mental wellbeing
  • Five ways to good mental wellbeing for different faiths (guides)
  • How to cope with loneliness


If you’re looking for ways to meet new people in London, check out these websites:

  • JustBe
  • London Lonely Girls Club
  • Men's Sheds
  • The Allegr Foundation
  • The Great Friendship Project


If you’re feeling isolated and would like to speak to someone, there are lots of helplines available, including:

  • Age UK (0800 055 6112)
  • The Silverline (0800 4 70 80 90) - a free telephone service for older people
  • Samaritans (116 123)
  • SHOUT (text SHOUT to 85258) - a free, confidential, text support service
  • The Mix (0800 808 4994) - free information and support for under 25s


You can also talk to your GP about how you’re feeling. They might be able to refer you to a social prescribing service, which connects patients with local community groups and adult learning opportunities.

tabs.title: Struggling with low mood?
tabs.content:
It’s normal to experience changes in mood as we move between seasons. One of the reasons you might experience low mood during the winter months is Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD). 

More than two million people in the UK are affected by SAD, a type of depression that often becomes more severe during the winter when there is less sunlight. The symptoms include lacking energy, being irritable, feeling sad, sleeping for longer and losing interest in the things you normally enjoy.

If low mood is affecting your daily life, you might like to:

  • Talk to your GP – during your consultation (either phone or face-to-face), they will assess you and suggest some things that might help.
  • Spend more time outside – sunlight can affect your body’s internal clock (circadian rhythm) as well as the production of the sleep hormone (melatonin) and the mood stabiliser (serotonin) so try to get outside as much as possible, especially around midday.
  • Connect with friends and relatives – spending time with other people can give you a focus and an energy boost as well as the opportunity to share how you’re feeling.
  • Exercise regularly – not only does this help your physical health, it can improve your mental wellbeing and enhance the quality of your sleep. Perhaps you could see what’s on offer at your local leisure centre or join a local sports club?
  • Track your activities and mood – in your diary or journal or in the Notes app on your phone, write down what you do each day and how it makes you feel then replace any activities that result in negative feelings (e.g. spending time alone at home) with more positive ones (e.g. going for a walk, having lunch with a friend or doing your favourite hobby).


Check out Good Thinking’s free resources to help you improve your mood: 

  • Five ways to good mental wellbeing
  • Five ways to good mental wellbeing for different faith (guides)
  • Free NHS-approved wellbeing apps
  • How to connect with nature to boost your wellbeing (article)


There is lots of advice and support available for Seasonal Affective Disorder. The following websites are a good place to start:

  • Mental Health Foundation
  • Mind
  • NHS 
  • Seasonal Affective Disorder Association

tabs.title: Concerned about someone else?
tabs.content:
Knowing if a family member, friend or colleague is struggling with their mental health and how you can help them can be difficult. 

It may not always be possible to spot the signs, so it’s really important to check how people are feeling and to create a safe and supportive space for them to open up. There is guidance available to help you encourage a gentle and supportive conversation and to know when this may be needed.

“Cold, dark days. Cost of living crisis. Loneliness. It’s all enough to make us sad… or give us SAD! Not helped by living in the season when we are supposed to be jolly... On the other hand, it is an opportunity for us to be kind to someone or to check in on those around us. Let’s face it, we all need some support for our mental health from time to time, and many of us are struggling with multiple challenges to our mental wellbeing.” - Dr Phil Moore, Emeritus Clinical Director Mental Health, NHS England (London)

If you think someone needs support this winter, check out the following resources for individuals and professionals from Good Thinking and Thrive LDN:

  • Good Thinking (quick guides for supporting others)
  • Good Thinking (‘Mental health and me’ guide)
  • Thrive LDN (mental health conversation starter) 
  • Thrive LDN and Healthy Dialogues (training for key workers and community champions) 
  • Thrive LDN (trauma-informed practice training) 
  • Zero Suicide Alliance (free online training for suicide prevention)

tabs.title: Need urgent support?
tabs.content:
When you’re worried about money, feeling lonely or struggling with low mood, you might start to feel completely overwhelmed. Please don’t suffer alone. 

If you’re very distressed, you can contact the following organisations for urgent support:

  • NHS 24/7 mental health crisis lines in London boroughs 
  • Samaritans (116 123)
  • SHOUT (text SHOUT to 85258)

If you need help urgently but are not at risk of harm or serious illness, call NHS 111.

If it’s an emergency situation, call 999.

results.subtitle: Are you dreading the end of the summer holidays? Good Thinking’s advice will help you to embrace what’s coming up.

metadata.description: Good Thinking provides 5 wellbeing tips to help children and young people maintain good mental health when returning to school.
metadata.title: Five wellbeing tips for going back to school

contentSections.content:
It’s perfectly normal to feel anxious and stressed as the start of the school year approaches. If you’re going to a new school, sixth form or college, for example, you might be nervous about having new teachers, getting used to a new timetable and making new friends. You’ll also have to shift from holiday mode into a more structured daily routine with early starts and homework in the evenings. 

Anxiety and stress can make you feel grumpy, tired and generally overwhelmed. It can even lead to headaches, tummy aches and other physical symptoms. If you’re struggling with any of these, this article by the Good Thinking team contains five tips to help you focus on what you can control and feel more positive. 

We’re here to help all Londoners boost their mental health – we hope you find our advice useful.

tabs.title: 1. Write down your concerns
tabs.content:
Putting your worries down on paper can be a really good way of dealing with any negative emotions and moving forward. Try the following technique:

  • Grab a pen and notebook, your laptop or your phone
  • Set a timer for five minutes
  • Write down a few specific things that you’re worried about (e.g. what if I don’t make any new friends?)
  • Next to each worry, write down how it makes you feel (e.g. anxious, down, stressed)
  • Come back to your list the next day and write down what you could do to deal with the worry (e.g. if you’re nervous about making new friends, could you travel to school with a sibling or find out in advance what school clubs/teams you could join?)
  • Make a list of the things you’re looking forward to and your hopes for this year as well

You might also like to start keeping a journal – read Good Thinking’s guidance on journaling.

tabs.title: 2. Do something fun
tabs.content:
Fill the last few days of the school holidays with things you enjoy doing (and try to make time for them once you're back at school). Perhaps you could:

  • Meet up with your friends – at the cinema, at a gig, in the park or at home
  • Go for a run or a bike ride or do a workout
  • Organise some volunteering work in your local community
  • Do something creative (e.g. take some photos or choreograph a dance)
  • Spend time in nature
  • Learn a new skill or improve one you already have (e.g. cooking or yoga)

Check out Good Thinking’s Five ways to wellbeing for children and young people for more suggestions.

tabs.title: 3. Be honest about how you feel
tabs.content:
One of the most important things you can do is talk to your family and friends about how you’re feeling so they can support you.

  • Think about what you want to say to them (you might like to write down your key points or refer to your list of worries from point 1)
  • Pick the right time and place to have the conversation so they can give you their full attention
  • Let them know how they can help you (e.g. offer advice, talk to your teacher, give you a hug) and be clear about what you don’t want them to do
  • Keep talking! Try to have regular conversations throughout the school year

Your friends might also be worried about going back to school – find out how you can help them in Good Thinking’s quick guide to looking out for your friends .

tabs.title: 4. Switch up your sleep routine
tabs.content:
During the holidays, you’ve probably been going to bed later and getting up later. So how can you get back into good sleep habits for the Autumn term? 

  • Try making bedtime a little earlier each night in the week before school (start with 15 minutes earlier tonight and increase this over the next few days) 
  • Set your alarm to help you get back into the habit of waking up at a specific time
  • Wind down properly before you go to bed (turn off your tech, have a warm drink, do some journaling)
  • Make sure your bedroom is dark, quiet and the right temperature
  • Put your phone on silent or leave it in another room

Learn more in Good Thinking’s one-pager about getting better sleep .

tabs.title: 5. Get further support if you need it
tabs.content:
You can find a range of free wellbeing resources on Good Thinking, including:

contentSections.content:
Are you about to sit exams at school, college or university? It’s an intense time so it’s perfectly natural to feel stressed about your studies and anxious about what the future holds. In fact, research by University College London (UCL) shows that young people are at heightened risk of mental health issues during exam season.

You might be worrying about the impact of low grades on your uni or job applications and you might feel under pressure from your family and teachers. If you’re a part-time or mature student, you might be juggling work and family commitments alongside your studies.

More than a third (36.7%) of 16 to 25-year-olds who took part in Partnership for Young London’s Levelling Up London survey cited ‘career’ as their biggest aspiration and we know that achieving GCSEs, A Levels, BTECs, degrees and other qualifications are key milestones in a young person’s journey to the workplace. So, it’s important to know how to cope with the pressure of exams.

First of all, remember that stress is a normal, even healthy, reaction to a threat (it prepares you for ‘fight or flight’). If it’s affecting you badly, however, one of the ways to manage it is by focusing on what you can control. It can be a small thing, either to do with your studies or something fun, but completing the activity will give you a feeling of achievement and help to boost your mood.

Good Thinking has put together these simple wellbeing tips for students of all ages across London. We hope you find them helpful and wish you all the best for your exams!

tabs.title: Get organised
tabs.content:
• Find a quiet place to revise, at home or in the library
  • Make a revision plan (set daily targets and try different study methods, such as mind maps and flash cards)
  • Do some mock exam questions against a timer
  • Join your friends in a study group
  • Limit distractions, such as social media notifications
  • Take a break from your revision every 30-45 minutes 
  • Make the most of Good Thinking’s free NHS-approved wellbeing apps, such as Clear Fear, and Sorted Teens, to help manage any feelings of anxiety
  • Find out what will happen on results day and how you can prepare for it (e.g. make sure your UCAS hub details are up-to-date and your phone is topped up and charged)

tabs.title: Look after yourself
tabs.content:
• Eat healthily, stay hydrated and avoid caffeine and other stimulants (read our advice on healthy eating) 
  • Keep active – whether you run, walk, do yoga or go to the gym, exercise is a great stressbuster 
  • Get enough sleep and try not to cram late at night before an exam (find out how to get better sleep)
  • If you’re going through lots of ‘What if…?' scenarios, use a meditation or mindfulness app (get more tips on dealing with uncertainty)
  • Reward yourself for putting the work in – perhaps you could watch your favourite TV show or cook a nice meal?

tabs.title: Don’t bottle things up
tabs.content:
• Have honest conversations with your friends about how you’re all coping and offer them your support (read our guide about looking out for your friends)
  • Tell your family how you’re feeling and how they can support you (they might find it helpful to read our guide for parents and carers and download the free Combined Minds app)
  • Speak to your teacher, tutor, wellbeing advisor or counsellor about any concerns you have
  • Share your thoughts and experiences in an online community (e.g. The Student Room)
  • Write down how you’re feeling (find out how to get started with journaling)

tabs.title: Strike a balance
tabs.content:
• Make time for doing the things you enjoy (art, sport, music etc) alongside your studies
  • Try to get outside for a walk every day (find out how to connect with nature to boost your wellbeing) 
  • Spend time with your friends and family as this can help to re-energise you
  • Make fun plans for after your exams so you have something to look forward to

tabs.title: Don’t panic
tabs.content:
• Go into your exams with a positive attitude but remember that your grades do not define you
  • If you feel anxious in the exam room, try doing some deep breathing  
  • Once you’ve finished the exam, forget about it – you can’t change anything now
  • Try not to compare yourself to other people on results day – be proud of what you’ve achieved
  • Even if you don’t get the grades you hoped for, remember that there will be lots of amazing opportunities available to you

contentSections.content:
And finally, here’s some advice from students at Birkbeck, University of London and Birkbeck Students' Union on how to cope with exam stress:

Pedro Malheiro, Student Leader, Birkbeck Students' Union

"As the Student Leader at Birkbeck, I understand how challenging exam season can be for students. The pressure to excel academically while maintaining optimal mental health and wellbeing can feel overwhelming. 

Be kind to yourself. It's normal to feel overwhelmed or anxious at times, but it's crucial to recognise that you're doing your best. Embrace your journey, trust your abilities, and remember that success is not solely defined by academic achievements but also by personal growth and resilience."


Tonya Moralez, LGBTQ+ Officer, Birkbeck Students' Union

"I usually do a 5-10 minute mindfulness meditation about 10 minutes before an exam. This helps me to calm any anxiety and regain focus after heavy revision before the exam. It allows me better control of my nerves and my concentration.

After an exam, I usually decompress with a bath and I allow mental activity to flow freely so that all of those jumbled, rapid thoughts can slow down and dissipate."


Ikenna Okoye-Ahaneku, Black Students' Officer, Birkbeck Students' Union

"I de-stress by taking breaks from studying occasionally, engaging in my hobbies that include listening to music, watching sports, watching films and TV, reading books and playing video games.

We are not robots – we need to have a balance between work and leisure, so we don’t burn out!

I also exercise, for example, jogging – studies have shown exercise is a great way to decrease stress and is good for our brains."
